Bink SDK 1.7b

Sharing the CPU on the Sony PS2

Discussion

On the Sony PS2, you don't have to share the CPU with the OS at all! This is the bonus of working on a console - you can hog all the CPU you want!

This means the typical Sony PS2 Bink playback loop is very simple. Bink handles timing with the BinkWait function, so we just need to check this function while we're playing a video.

So, a simple example of Sony PS2 playback would look something like this: 

for ( ; ; )
{
   // check on our playback
   if ( !BinkWait( bink ) )
   {
     BinkDoFrame( bink );
     // wait until the previous frame has been uploaded
     wait_for_DMA_to_complete();
     // copy into an RGB32
     BinkCopyToBuffer( bink, ... );
     // start uploading the video frame
     start_DMAing_the_video_frame();
     // move to the next frame
     BinkNextFrame( bink ); 
   }
 }
}
